entry.title: Building CI/CD Pipelines with IDEA, Gitlab, Jenkins and Kubernetes - Topic 2.3 - Jenkins (Pull, Build and Deploy)
entry.content:
Pipeline Project tutorial

  1. Hello, Declarative Pipeline Script
    (1). select New Item from dashboard

    (2). select Pipeline project and OK

    (3). find Pipeline on project configuration, select Hello World

    (4). Hello World script will display

    (5). customize, apply and save

    (6). build test


    done!

  2. Hello, Scripted Pipeline Script
    (1). select New Item from dashboard

    (2). select Pipeline project and OK

    (3). find Pipeline on project configuration, select Scripted Pipeline

    (4). Scripted Pipeline script will display
    customize

    (5). build test, done!

  3. Start a pipeline project
    (1). back to project

    (2). add pull script

    • initialize, and select Pipeline Syntax
    • select steps -> checkout
    • fill Git form
    • Generate Pipeline Script and copy generated string
    • paste it to Pull stage on Pipeline script configuration
    • pull test
    • done!

    (3). add build script

    • generate build script from Pipeline Syntax

    • paste it to Build stage on Pipeline script configuration, apply and save
    • build test
    • done!

    (4). add deploy script

    • back to project
    • generate script from Pipeline Syntax
    • paste it to Deploy stage on Pipeline script configuration, apply and save
    • deploy test
    • done!

  4. Start a pipeline project from SCM (for version control)
    (1). add Jenkinsfile on root directory


    (2). copy Pipeline script configuration

    (3). paste it on Jenkinsfile

    (4). commit


    (5). push



    (6). change Pipeline->Definition to Pipeline script from SCM

    (7). fill Git form

    (8). done!

entry.title: Building CI/CD Pipelines with IDEA, Gitlab, Jenkins and Kubernetes - Topic 2.2 - Jenkins (Pull, Build and Deploy)
entry.content:
Freestyle and Maven Project tutorial

  1. Install Maven
    (1). sudo apt-get install maven

    (2). sudo vim /etc/profile

    (3). source /etc/profile

    (4). mvn -v

    (5). sudo vim /usr/share/maven/conf/settings.xml

    (6). Configure Maven on Jenkins

    • Global Tool Configuration

      add JDK


      add Maven
    • Configure System


      fill “Environment variables” form, apple and save

    (7). Test Maven

    • select the “ssh-item” (we did before)

    • select Configuration
    • find Build
    • add Execute shell, apply and save
    • click Build now
    • check output
    • done!

  2. Install Tomcat
    (1). sudo apt-get install tomcat9

    (2). the default port is 9000 (NAT by 29000 here)

    (3). we need an admin account

    (4). sudo vi /etc/tomcat9/tomcat-users.xml

    (5). sudo vi /etc/tomcat9/server.xml option

    (6). sudo systemctl enable tomcat9
    (7). sudo systemctl restart tomcat9
    (8). done!

  3. Test and deploy an application
    (1) Freestyle project

    • create it
    • get git url

    • pull test


    • set up build settings


    • build test

    • install deploy plugin


    • configure deployment settings



    • add credential for tomcat

    • test deploy

    • done!

    (2). Maven project

    • install Maven Integration


    • create maven project


    • set up build settings
    • configure deployment settings

    • test it

    • error caused by jenkins jdk
    • add correct jdk
    • configure project jdk

    • build it again
    • done!

Reference
https://linuxconfig.org/ubuntu-20-04-tomcat-installation

entry.title: Building CI/CD Pipelines with IDEA, Gitlab, Jenkins and Kubernetes - Topic 2.1 - Jenkins (Pull Project from Gitlab)
entry.content:
“The leading open source automation server, Jenkins provides hundreds of plugins to support building, deploying and automating any project.” - jenkins.io

  1. Install
    1.1 install Jenkins

    • (1) sudo apt-get install openjdk-8-jdk

    • (2). wget -q -O - https://pkg.jenkins.io/debian-stable/jenkins.io.key | sudo apt-key add -

    • (3).

    • (4). sudo apt-get update

    • (5). sudo apt-get install jenkins

    • (6). sudo vim /etc/default/jenkins

    • (7). sudo vim /etc/init.d/jenkins

    • (8). sudo systemctl enable jenkins

    • (9). sudo systemctl start jenkins

    • (10). first login

    • (11). sudo cat /var/lib/jenkins/secrets/initialAdminPassword

    • (12). copy and paste the password

    • (13). select “Install suggested plugins”

    • (14). create first admin user

    • (15). set jenkins url

    • (16). jenkins is ready

    1.2 install “Role-based Authorization Strategy” plugin

    • (1). login
    • (2). Manage Jenkins -> Manage Plugins

    • (3). select “Available” tab and search “Role-based Authorization Strategy”
    • (4). mark it and click “Download now and install after restart”


    • (5). login
    • (6). Manage Jenkins -> Configure Global Security
    • (7). change “Authorization Strategy” to “Role-Base Strategy” and save
    • (8). go back to “Manage Jenkins”
    • (9). find “Manage and Assign Roles”

    • (10). select “Manage Roles”
    • (11). add base role

    • (12). add item roles (for projects)
    • (13). apply and save
    • (14). go back to “Manage Jenkins”
    • (15). select “Manage Users”
    • (16). create test users (charlie and david)


    • (17). login with charlie

      oops
    • (18). login with admin bob
    • (19). assign role to charlie, Manage Jenkins->”Manage and Assign Roles”

    • (20). login with charlie again (OK)
    • (21). login with bob again, assign roles to charlie and david
    • (22). create projects for testing roles





    • (23). charlie’s view
    • (24). david’s view

  2. Add credentials
    2.1 by username and password

    • (1). Manage Jenkins->Manage Credentials

    • (2). click “global”
    • (3). add credential

    • (4). back to dashboard
    • (5). select a project
    • (6). fill git form


    • (7). save, back to project and “Build Now”
    • (8). click “Build History” item
    • (9). check “Console Output”, done!

    2.2 by ssh

    • (1). ssh-keygen -t rsa
    • (2). cd /home/webdev/.ssh/ && llid_rsa and id_rsa.pub are important!
    • (3). add ssh key on Gitlab
      • login Gitlab
      • add id_rsa.pub content to settings -> SSH Keys


    • (4). add ssh key on Jenkins
      • enter “Manage Credentials”

      • add ssh credential by the id_rsa content

    • (5). back to dashboard
    • (6). “New Item”
    • (7). get ssh url from Gitlab project
    • (8). fill git form on Jenkins, apply and save
    • (9). “Build Now”
    • (10). check the result, done!

Reference
https://openjdk.java.net/install/
https://www.jenkins.io/doc/book/installing/#debianubuntu
entry.summary: “The leading open source automation server, Jenkins provides hundreds of plugins to support building, deploying and automating any project.” - jenkins.io

entry.title: Building CI/CD Pipelines with IDEA, Gitlab, Jenkins and Kubernetes - Topic 1 - Gitlab
entry.content:
“Take your version control to the next level” - Gitlab.com

  1. Install Gitlab (Ubuntu 20.04 LTS)
    (1). sudo apt-get update

    (2). sudo apt-get install -y curl openssh-server

    (3). sudo apt-get install -y postfix

    • Quit the package configuration by selecting cancel in the Installing

    (4). sudo apt-get install -y curl openssh-server

    (5). Maybe there a problem on Ubuntu 20.04 LTS: [Unable to locate package gitlab-ee], so two logs here.

    • curl https://packages.gitlab.com/install/repositories/gitlab/gitlab-ee/script.deb.sh | sudo bash

      • sudo apt-get install gitlab-ee

    • curl https://packages.gitlab.com/install/repositories/gitlab/gitlab-ee/script.deb.sh | sudo os=ubuntu dist=bionic bash

      • sudo apt-get install gitlab-ee

    (6). sudo vi /etc/gitlab/gitlab.rb

    (7). sudo gitlab-ctl reconfigure
    (8). sudo gitlab-ctl restart

    Tips. useful commends (something went wrong while installing)

    (9). Done!

  2. Test Gitlab
    (1). Change your(root) password and login



    (2). Create new group


    (3). Create new project (button on the top-right)


    (4). Enter admin area (icon on the top)

    (5). New user



    (6). Set user password

    save changes


    (7). Add user to project
    display your group

    select group


    select user

    select a role

    click invite


    (8). Log in with added user

    set new password (while first login)

    (9). Dashboard of your project

    (10). Enable Version Controll Integration on IDEA



    (11). Git to local
    add


    commit





    (12). Set remote git repo.


    copy repo. url

    and paste

    (13). Set login user


    (14). Push!



    (15). Done!
entry.summary: “Take your version control to the next level” - Gitlab.com

entry.title: What's the Difference Between CI and CD (and the Other CD)?
entry.content:
• Abstract from RedHat [What is CI/CD?]

    • Continuous integration (CI) helps developers merge their code changes back to a shared branch, or “trunk,” more frequently—sometimes even daily. If automated testing discovers a conflict between new and existing code, CI makes it easier to fix those bugs quickly and often.
    • Continuous delivery (CD), the goal of continuous delivery is to have a codebase that is always ready for deployment to a production environment.
    • Continuous deployment (CD), as an extension of continuous delivery, continuous deployment means that a developer’s change to a cloud application could go live within minutes of writing it (assuming it passes automated testing). This makes it much easier to continuously receive and incorporate user feedback.

 

  • Relationship Diagram

    1. Red Hat, Inc.

      Source: https://www.redhat.com/en/topics/devops/what-is-ci-cd

    2. Code Maze

      Source: https://www.codeproject.com/articles/1078439/what-is-continuous-integration-and-why-do-you-need

Reference
https://www.redhat.com/en/topics/devops/what-is-ci-cd
http://devopstechie.com/continuous-integration-vs-continuous-delivery-vs-continuous-deployment/
entry.summary:
• Abstract from RedHat [What is CI/CD?]

    • Continuous integration (CI) helps developers merge their code changes back to a shared branch, or “trunk,” more frequently—sometimes even daily. If automated testing discovers a conflict between new and existing code, CI makes it easier to fix those bugs quickly and often.
    • Continuous delivery (CD), the goal of continuous delivery is to have a codebase that is always ready for deployment to a production environment.
    • Continuous deployment (CD), as an extension of continuous delivery, continuous deployment means that a developer’s change to a cloud application could go live within minutes of writing it (assuming it passes automated testing). This makes it much easier to continuously receive and incorporate user feedback.

entry.title: Get Started with Docker on Ubuntu 20.04 LTS
entry.content:
“We have a complete container solution for you - no matter who you are and where you are on your containerization journey.” - Docker Inc.

  1. sudo apt install docker.io

  2. Manage Docker as a non-root user

  3. docker search hello-world

  4. docker pull hello-world

  5. docker run hello-world

Reference
Docker Official Website
Docker Docs
Docker Hub
entry.summary: “We have a complete container solution for you - no matter who you are and where you are on your containerization journey.” - Docker Inc.

entry.title: Building a Spring Boot Application Using Intellij IDEA
entry.content:
“Spring makes programming Java quicker, easier, and safer for everybody. Spring’s focus on speed, simplicity, and productivity has made it the world’s most popular Java framework.” - spring.io

  1. Install IntelliJ IDEA
  2. Start IntelliJ IDEA and Create New Project
  3. Select Spring Initializr -> Project SDK




    and Next.
  4. Project Settings (Optional)

    and Next.
  5. Select Dependencies (Enable Web -> Spring Web Here)

    and Next.
  6. Select Project Location
  7. Setup Maven (a build automation tool used primarily for Java projects)
    (1). File -> Settings

    (2). Build, Execution and Deployment -> Build Tools -> Maven

    (3). Download Apache Maven (https://maven.apache.org/) and Create a Folder for Maven Repository

    (4). Setup Apache Maven folder -> conf folder -> settings.xml


    (5). Fill Maven home directory, User settings file and Local repository in Intellij IDEA settings.

    Apply and OK
    (6). We Got Some Error Information from Default Maven Settings Here

    (7). Click Reload All Maven Projects on Top-Right Corner, and Wait for Maven Import Completion

    (8). Errors were resolved
  8. Create a Simple Web Application
  9. Click Run DemoApplication Button on Top-Right Corner (Shift + F10)
  10. Done!

Reference
IntelliJ IDEA Official Website
Spring Official Website
Apache Maven Official Website
entry.summary: “Spring makes programming Java quicker, easier, and safer for everybody. Spring’s focus on speed, simplicity, and productivity has made it the world’s most popular Java framework.” - spring.io

entry.title: Access Localhost from Anywhere with Ngrok
entry.content:
Public URLs for exposing your local web server.

  1. https://ngrok.com/download

  2. Example:
    (1). Usage on Windows (my host machine).

    (2). To expose web server with a HTTP tunnel on port 23000 on Windows.

    ngrok http 23000

    (3). We can surf the web from anywhere now.

Reference
ngrok Official Website
entry.summary: Public URLs for exposing your local web server.

entry.title: Installation of React on Ubuntu 20.04 LTS
entry.content:
A JavaScript library for building user interfaces.

  1. Install Node.js

  2. sudo npm install -g create-react-app

  3. cd hello-app; npm start

  4. Done!

Reference:
React Official Website
Install And Setup React App on Ubuntu 18.04.3 LTS
Thumbnail
entry.summary: A JavaScript library for building user interfaces.

entry.title: Installation of Node.js on Ubuntu 20.04 LTS
entry.content:
Node.js® is a JavaScript runtime built on Chrome’s V8 JavaScript engine.

  1. sudo apt-get install curl

  2. curl -sL https://deb.nodesource.com/setup_12.x | sudo -E bash -

  3. sudo apt-get install -y nodejs

  4. sudo npm install npm@latest -g

Reference:
Node.js Official Website
Install And Setup React App on Ubuntu 18.04.3 LTS
entry.summary: Node.js® is a JavaScript runtime built on Chrome’s V8 JavaScript engine.

entry.title: Online Markdown Editor
entry.content:
• https://pandao.github.io/editor.md/en.html
  • https://dillinger.io/
  • https://stackedit.io/app

Sample (from Editor.md)

Features

  • Support Standard Markdown / CommonMark and GFM(GitHub Flavored Markdown);
  • Full-featured: Real-time Preview, Image (cross-domain) upload, Preformatted text/Code blocks/Tables insert, Code fold, Search replace, Read only, Themes, Multi-languages, L18n, HTML entities, Code syntax highlighting…;
  • Markdown Extras : Support ToC (Table of Contents), Emoji, Task lists, @Links…;
  • Compatible with all major browsers (IE8+), compatible Zepto.js and iPad;
  • Support identification, interpretation, fliter of the HTML tags;
  • Support TeX (LaTeX expressions, Based on KaTeX), Flowchart and Sequence Diagram of Markdown extended syntax;
  • Support AMD/CMD (Require.js & Sea.js) Module Loader, and Custom/define editor plugins;

Editor.md

##Headers (Underline)

H1 Header (Underline)

H2 Header (Underline)

Characters

Strikethrough Strikethrough (when enable html tag decode.)
Italic Italic
Emphasis Emphasis
Emphasis Italic Emphasis Italic

Superscript: X2，Subscript: O2

Abbreviation(link HTML abbr tag)

The HTML specification is maintained by the W3C.

Blockquotes

Blockquotes

Paragraphs and Line Breaks

“Blockquotes Blockquotes”, Link。

Links

Links

Links with title

<link> : https://github.com

Reference link

GFM a-tail link @pandao

Code Blocks (multi-language) & highlighting

Inline code

$ npm install marked

Code Blocks (Indented style)

Indented 4 spaces, like <pre> (Preformatted Text).

<?php    echo "Hello world!";?>

Code Blocks (Preformatted text):

| First Header  | Second Header || ------------- | ------------- || Content Cell  | Content Cell  || Content Cell  | Content Cell  |

Javascript　

HTML code

Images

Image:

Follow your heart.

图为：厦门白城沙滩 Xiamen

图片加链接 (Image + Link)：

图为：李健首张专辑《似水流年》封面

Lists

Unordered list (-)

  • Item A
  • Item B
  • Item C

Unordered list (*)

  • Item A
  • Item B
  • Item C

Unordered list (plus sign and nested)

  • Item A
  • Item B
    • Item B 1
    • Item B 2
    • Item B 3
  • Item C
    • Item C 1
    • Item C 2
    • Item C 3

Ordered list

  1. Item A
  2. Item B
  3. Item C

Tables

First HeaderSecond Header
Content CellContent Cell
Content CellContent Cell

Content CellContent Cell
Content CellContent Cell
Function nameDescription

destroy()Destroy your computer!
ItemValue

& < > ¥ € ® ± ¶ § ¦ ¯ « ·

X² Y³ ¾ ¼ × ÷ »

##Escaping for Special Characters

*literal asterisks*

  • :smiley: @mentions, :smiley: #refs, links, formatting, and tags supported :editormd-logo:;
  • list syntax required (any unordered or ordered list supported) :editormd-logo-3x:;
  • [ ] :smiley: this is a complete item :smiley:;
  • []this is an incomplete item test link :fa-star: @pandao;
  • [ ]this is an incomplete item :fa-star: :fa-gear:;
    • :smiley: this is an incomplete item test link :fa-star: :fa-gear:;

Inline $$E=mc^2$$ Inline，Inline $$E=mc^2$$ Inline。
